* Port to bouncycastle cryptography
* fix X509SignatureFactory.cs for latest bouncy castle

Make CertificateValidationEventArgs and CertificateUpdateEventArgs constructors public (#2329)

Making these constructors public will unblock testing important scenarios.

.NET target 5.0 and 6.0 use 6.0 version of Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.Abstractions (#2335)

Referencing package OPCFoundation.NetStandard.Opc.Ua.Core from a .NET6 targeted project that in it self are using Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.Abstractions 6.0.4 will cause downgrade problems.

Instead for .NET6 targeted applications reference 6.0.x versions of Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.Abstractions.

Added new DataTypes to Reference Server (#2340)

Three new DataTypes plus Variables containing them were added to the Reference Server:
- VectorUnion (as Scalar and Array): The VectorUnion contains three fields (X, Y, Z) and a SwitchField. When it is used as value, it is generated randomly (SwitchField set to None or one of the Fields)
- VectorWithOptionalFields (as Scalar and Array): The VectorWithOptionalFields contains again three fields (X, Y, Z), but they are all optional. When it is used as a value, it is generated with 0 to all fields activated.
- MultipleVectors (as Scalar and Array): The MultipleVectors type contains 6 Components. A regular Vector, a VectorUnion (from before), a VectorWithOptionalFields (also from before) and the same as Arrays.

Add property to disable auto certificate creation on app startup (#2348)

- Add a property to `ApplicationInstance` to `DisableCertificateAutoCreation`
- Add the test case to validate property function
- Refactor some private API to follow coding style with `Async`suffix
- By default behavior is unchanged

Various async improvements and minor issues found in IOP testing (#2346)

- improve various log messages, comments etc.
- multiple internal improvements in naming convention handling of async functions
- add FetchSuperTypesAsync
- replace new UTFEncoding() with Encoding.UTF8 singleton

Nested complex types which contain structure derived from an abstract type are not correctly encoded (#2349)

- bug: if the nested complex type is derived from an abstract type like a Union, the decoder uses the abstract type instead of the actual type to decode
- fix: the loop to determine the supertype of the type to be decoded stops too early and returns an invalid type reference, e.g. for Unions. Instead the loop will now continue until a valid BuiltInType or a Structure or Enumeration type is found.

## Types of changes

What types of changes does your code introduce?
_Put an `x` in the boxes that apply. You can also fill these out after creating the PR._

- [x] Bugfix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)

issue.title: Version numbering - SemVer 2.0.0 compliance
issue.body:
### Type of issue

- [ ] Bug
- [ ] Enhancement
- [X] Compliance
- [ ] Question
- [ ] Help wanted

### Current Behavior

Important code changes, like bug fixes, changes of behaviour and even changes in the interfaces, are sometimes visible only in the changing of the 4-th number in the version number, e.g. differences between 1.4.371.41 and 1.4.371.96.
These important changes are not optimally detected by the nuget package manager of Visual Studio, which seems to pay attention only to the first three portions of the version numbers, like in SemVer 2.0.0.

### Expected Behavior

Please comply with the SemVer 2.0.0 and use only major.minor.patch for the releases, so that the IDEs like Visual Studio can correctly detect the important changes.
Important changes like the exponential backoff by the SessionReconnectHandler might be missed by some developers, because they think that should pay attention only to changes in the major-minor-patch part of the version numbers. So, someone who took e.g. version 1.4.371.41 will have different behaviour compared with a coleague that took 1.4.371.96, only because they both use "1.4.371" in the file package.config, but compile the solution at different moments in time.

### Steps To Reproduce

_No response_

### Environment

```markdown
- OS:
- Environment:
    Visual Studio 2019
- Runtime:
- Nuget Version:
- Component:
- Server:
- Client:
```


### Anything else?

_No response_

comment.body:
Hi @stefanluchian, unfortunately we carry a baggage here, which is the spec version. 
The spec version is 1.04 or 1.05 next, so our first two digits are preset. An option were to make a 14 or 15. But the reference to a 1.3 or 1.5 spec version seems important.
Then the next number is one that is increased when there is a 'breaking change', e.g. 371->372
The last number is the build number since the commit for the breaking change was updated.
Imho there is currently no better solution, unless you have some idea.

issue.title: XmlEncoder/Decoder always use the OPC UA XML namespace for the containing field of a one-dimensional array
issue.body:
### Type of issue

- [X] Bug
- [ ] Enhancement
- [ ] Compliance
- [ ] Question
- [ ] Help wanted

### Current Behavior

XmlEncoder.WriteArray and XmlDecoder.ReadArray always use the OPC UA XML namespace (http://opcfoundation.org/UA/2008/02/Types.xsd) for the field element that contains the array, regardless of the namespace that the caller may have pushed.

### Expected Behavior

The containing field should be in the XML namespace pushed by the caller, as it is for all other ReadXYZ/WriteXYZ methods.

### Steps To Reproduce

See updated test case in PR #2309 .

### Environment

```markdown
- OS: Windows 11, Ubuntu
- Environment: VS
- Runtime: .Net 6.0
- Nuget Version: 1.4.372.56
- Component: Opc.Ua.Core
- Server:
- Client:
```


### Anything else?

For example, the following XML snippet from the [http://opcfoundation.org/UA/TMC/](https://reference.opcfoundation.org/nodesets/97) nodeset can not be decoded/encoded because MaterialCapability is an array and always assumed to be in the uax namespace:

```xml
 <Value>
      <uax:ListOfExtensionObject xmlns:uax="http://opcfoundation.org/UA/2008/02/Types.xsd">
        <uax:ExtensionObject>
          <uax:TypeId>
            <uax:Identifier>ns=1;i=5040</uax:Identifier>
          </uax:TypeId>
          <uax:Body>
            <LoadUnloadPointType xmlns="http://opcfoundation.org/UA/TMC/Types.xsd">
              <ID>
              </ID>
              <Description />
              <MaterialCapability />
              <UserName>
              </UserName>
              <MES_ID>
              </MES_ID>
            </LoadUnloadPointType>
          </uax:Body>
        </uax:ExtensionObject>
      </uax:ListOfExtensionObject>
    </Value>
```

issue.title: Support for BigInteger cast in TypeInfo ?
issue.body:
### Type of issue

- [ ] Bug
- [X] Enhancement
- [ ] Compliance
- [X] Question
- [ ] Help wanted

### Current Behavior

Would it make sense to add support for BigInteger to the TypeInfo class?

My application receives a value from a JSON message that it then writes to an OPC UA node.
The value is deserialized as a BigInteger when the value is a large number like UInt64.MaxValue.

I already use TypeInfo.Cast for all other values that can be received via the JSON message, but BigInteger currently cannot be converted and the cast returns null.

```C#
using Opc.Ua;
using System.Numerics;

Console.WriteLine("Converting BigInteger....");

var bigInteger = new BigInteger(UInt64.MaxValue);

var uint64Integer = TypeInfo.Cast(bigInteger, BuiltInType.UInt64);

Console.WriteLine($"Converted: {uint64Integer}");

**Actual Output:**

Converting BigInteger....
Converted: 
```

### Expected Behavior

**Expected Output:**

Converting BigInteger....
Converted:  18446744073709551615

### Steps To Reproduce

_No response_

### Environment

```markdown
- OS:
- Environment:
- Runtime:
- Nuget Version:
- Component:
- Server:
- Client:
```


### Anything else?

_No response_

issue.title: GetBuiltInType for abstract numeric types Number, Integer and UInteger return null
issue.body:
### Type of issue

- [ ] Bug
- [ ] Enhancement
- [ ] Compliance
- [X] Question
- [X] Help wanted

### Current Behavior

When calling TypeInfo.GetBuiltInType() for a node that has an abstract numeric data type like Number, Integer, UInteger, the value returned is null.
I had a look in the TypeInfo code and I can see the logic that returns null:

```
if (builtInType > BuiltInType.DiagnosticInfo && builtInType != BuiltInType.Enumeration)
{
    return BuiltInType.Null;
}
```

But I do not understand why.
At the moment I am trying to write a value to a node that has one of the abstract numeric datatypes.
In order to do this, I need to convert my value accordingly.
I cannot do this without knowing if I am dealing with a Number, Integer or UInteger.

Any help, suggestions and/or explanations will be appreciated.


```
var builtInType = TypeInfo.GetBuiltInType(new NodeId(28));

Console.WriteLine(builtInType);
```

Actual Output:
Null

### Expected Behavior

TypeInfo.GetBuiltInType() should return the corresponding BuitInType for Number, Integer and UInteger data types.

```
var builtInType = TypeInfo.GetBuiltInType(new NodeId(28));

Console.WriteLine(builtInType);
```

Expected Output:
UInteger

### Steps To Reproduce

_No response_

### Environment

```markdown
- OS:
- Environment:
- Runtime:
- Nuget Version:
- Component:
- Server:
- Client:
```


### Anything else?

_No response_

issue.title: How can I write a byte[] using this client?
issue.body:
### Type of issue

- [ ] Bug
- [ ] Enhancement
- [ ] Compliance
- [X] Question
- [X] Help wanted

### Current Behavior

When I read a byte[] from a server (e.g. S7-1500) it will work but the Variant inside the DataValue will have the typeInfo ByteString which is logical since the c'tor for the variant with byte[] sets the m_typeInfo to TypeInfo.Scalars.ByteString ... 
This is also very comfortable for ByteString handling.
But what I can't get to work is now writing this ByteArray back to the server since it'll be encoded like a ByteString and therefore the server won't accept the value provided.


### Expected Behavior

It is possible to write the value that I got from the Read.

### Steps To Reproduce

1. Create a server with an array of byte that is readable and writable
2. Connect to the server with the client to read that variable
3. Try to write that variable with the value you got from 2.

### Environment

```markdown
- OS: Windows 10
- Environment: 
- Runtime:
- Nuget Version: 1.4.366 but I could see the same Variant implementation in the current repository
- Component: 
- Server: S7-1500 V3.0
- Client: .NETStandard
```


### Anything else?

I cant attach the wireshark recording so I'll attach screenshots.
![variant_byServer](https://github.com/OPCFoundation/UA-.NETStandard/assets/47225814/ad9c35bd-db5c-4443-bf6c-7e6b84f3e611)
![client_read](https://github.com/OPCFoundation/UA-.NETStandard/assets/47225814/e794e7eb-c579-4ee4-910a-153e6abc7eae)
![client_write](https://github.com/OPCFoundation/UA-.NETStandard/assets/47225814/adca30e0-7cc4-4dac-a969-82532ec6c872)
![variant_by_client](https://github.com/OPCFoundation/UA-.NETStandard/assets/47225814/8d1ee76a-8e5f-478a-a4da-e14b54db712a)
![server_response](https://github.com/OPCFoundation/UA-.NETStandard/assets/47225814/bbb5b579-a1de-44cd-8f22-440de8be7e9f)

issue.title: How can I write a byte[] using this client?
issue.body:
### Type of issue

- [ ] Bug
- [ ] Enhancement
- [ ] Compliance
- [X] Question
- [X] Help wanted

### Current Behavior

When I read a byte[] from a server (e.g. S7-1500) it will work but the Variant inside the DataValue will have the typeInfo ByteString which is logical since the c'tor for the variant with byte[] sets the m_typeInfo to TypeInfo.Scalars.ByteString ... 
This is also very comfortable for ByteString handling.
But what I can't get to work is now writing this ByteArray back to the server since it'll be encoded like a ByteString and therefore the server won't accept the value provided.


### Expected Behavior

It is possible to write the value that I got from the Read.

### Steps To Reproduce

1. Create a server with an array of byte that is readable and writable
2. Connect to the server with the client to read that variable
3. Try to write that variable with the value you got from 2.

### Environment

```markdown
- OS: Windows 10
- Environment: 
- Runtime:
- Nuget Version: 1.4.366 but I could see the same Variant implementation in the current repository
- Component: 
- Server: S7-1500 V3.0
- Client: .NETStandard
```


### Anything else?

I cant attach the wireshark recording so I'll attach screenshots.

comment.body: I can/should probably also try it out with the current implementation, I just saw that the variant implementation for byte[] is still the same.

issue.title: How can I write a byte[] using this client?
issue.body:
### Type of issue

- [ ] Bug
- [ ] Enhancement
- [ ] Compliance
- [X] Question
- [X] Help wanted

### Current Behavior

When I read a byte[] from a server (e.g. S7-1500) it will work but the Variant inside the DataValue will have the typeInfo ByteString which is logical since the c'tor for the variant with byte[] sets the m_typeInfo to TypeInfo.Scalars.ByteString ... 
This is also very comfortable for ByteString handling.
But what I can't get to work is now writing this ByteArray back to the server since it'll be encoded like a ByteString and therefore the server won't accept the value provided.


### Expected Behavior

It is possible to write the value that I got from the Read.

### Steps To Reproduce

1. Create a server with an array of byte that is readable and writable
2. Connect to the server with the client to read that variable
3. Try to write that variable with the value you got from 2.

### Environment

```markdown
- OS: Windows 10
- Environment: 
- Runtime:
- Nuget Version: 1.4.366 but I could see the same Variant implementation in the current repository
- Component: 
- Server: S7-1500 V3.0
- Client: .NETStandard
```


### Anything else?

I cant attach the wireshark recording so I'll attach screenshots.
![variant_byServer](https://github.com/OPCFoundation/UA-.NETStandard/assets/47225814/ad9c35bd-db5c-4443-bf6c-7e6b84f3e611)
![client_read](https://github.com/OPCFoundation/UA-.NETStandard/assets/47225814/e794e7eb-c579-4ee4-910a-153e6abc7eae)
![client_write](https://github.com/OPCFoundation/UA-.NETStandard/assets/47225814/adca30e0-7cc4-4dac-a969-82532ec6c872)
![variant_by_client](https://github.com/OPCFoundation/UA-.NETStandard/assets/47225814/8d1ee76a-8e5f-478a-a4da-e14b54db712a)
![server_response](https://github.com/OPCFoundation/UA-.NETStandard/assets/47225814/bbb5b579-a1de-44cd-8f22-440de8be7e9f)

commits.message:
Nested complex types which contain structure derived from an abstract type are not correctly encoded (#2349)

- bug: if the nested complex type is derived from an abstract type like a Union, the decoder uses the abstract type instead of the actual type to decode
- fix: the loop to determine the supertype of the type to be decoded stops too early and returns an invalid type reference, e.g. for Unions. Instead the loop will now continue until a valid BuiltInType or a Structure or Enumeration type is found.

pull_request.title: Nested complex types which contain structure derived from an abstract type are not correctly encoded
pull_request.body:
## Proposed changes

- bug: if the nested complex type is derived from an abstract type like a Union, the decoder uses the abstract type instead of the actual type to decode
- fix: the loop to determine the supertype of the type to be decoded stops too early and returns an invalid type reference, e.g. for Unions. Instead the loop will now continue until a valid BuiltInType or a Structure or Enumeration type is found.
- Repro with nested complex types, as created in the new types in the reference server: #2340
Other fixes: 
- Stricter testing of decoded size vs. object size to catch cases of invalid decoding when the decoding remains within the buffer size
- Fix the complex type tester to catch complex types which are decoded as ExtensionObject instead of the actual type
- Fix an issue in the browse of the address space due to a small buffer, so fetch did not return all variables as requested
- Add a helper method to clear the internal NodeIdDictionary if memory is tight

Note: more 

## Related Issues

- Fixes #2340 
- Fixes https://github.com/Azure/Industrial-IoT/issues/2090

## Types of changes

What types of changes does your code introduce?
_Put an `x` in the boxes that apply. You can also fill these out after creating the PR._

- [x] Bugfix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)
- [ ] Enhancement (non-breaking change which adds functionality)
- [ ] Test enhancement (non-breaking change to increase test coverage)
- [ ] Breaking change (fix or feature that would cause existing functionality to not work as expected, requires version increase of Nuget packages)
- [ ] Documentation Update (if none of the other choices apply)

## Checklist

_Put an `x` in the boxes that apply. You can also fill these out after creating the PR. If you're unsure about any of them, don't hesitate to ask. We're here to help! This is simply a reminder of what we are going to look for before merging your code._

- [x] I have read the [CONTRIBUTING](https://github.com/OPCFoundation/UA-.NETStandard/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md) doc.
- [x] I have signed the [CLA](https://opcfoundation.org/license/cla/ContributorLicenseAgreementv1.0.pdf).
- [ ] I ran tests locally with my changes, all passed.
- [ ] I fixed all failing tests in the CI pipelines. 
- [ ] I fixed all introduced issues with CodeQL and LGTM.
- [ ] I have added tests that prove my fix is effective or that my feature works and increased code coverage.
- [ ] I have added necessary documentation (if appropriate).
- [ ] Any dependent changes have been merged and published in downstream modules.

## Further comments

If this is a relatively large or complex change, kick off the discussion by explaining why you chose the solution you did and what alternatives you considered, etc...

commits.message: fix opaque types

pull_request.title: Nested complex types which contain structure derived from an abstract type are not correctly encoded
pull_request.body:
## Proposed changes

- bug: if the nested complex type is derived from an abstract type like a Union, the decoder uses the abstract type instead of the actual type to decode
- fix: the loop to determine the supertype of the type to be decoded stops too early and returns an invalid type reference, e.g. for Unions. Instead the loop will now continue until BaseDataType or structure or enumeration is found.
- Repro with nested complex types, as created in the new types in the reference server: #2340
Other fixes: 
- Stricter testing of decoded size vs. object size to catch cases of invalid decoding when the decoding remains within the buffer size
- Fix the complex type tester to catch complex types which are decoded as ExtensionObject instead of the actual type
- Fix an issue in the browse of the address space due to a small buffer, so fetch did not return all variables as requested
- Add a helper method to clear the internal NodeIdDictionary if memory is tight

Note: more 

## Related Issues

- Fixes #2340 
- Fixes https://github.com/Azure/Industrial-IoT/issues/2090

issue.body:

commits.message: Temporary commit

Various async improvements and minor issues found in IOP testing (#2346)

- improve various log messages, comments etc.
- multiple internal improvements in naming convention handling of async functions
- add FetchSuperTypesAsync
- replace new UTFEncoding() with Encoding.UTF8 singleton
Merge remote-tracking branch 'origin/master' into complextypes
fix tests
